clinical_study.brief_title: Atorvastatin for Prevention of Postoperative Atrial Fibrillation After Off-Pump Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of Atorvastatin on the Occurrence of Postoperative Atrial Fibrillation After Off-Pump Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether pretreatment with atorvastatin protects against atrial fibrillation following off-pump coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Atrial fibrillation after cardiac surgery is the most common arrhythmic complication that may increase incidence of congestive heart failure, renal insufficiency, and stroke, which increase the length of hospital stay, the rates of re-hospitalization, and cost of care. Its pathogenesis is multifactorial, and its prevention and management remain suboptimal. Recently, observational evidence has suggested that patients who have undergone previous statin therapy have a lower incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.
The purpose of this study is to determine whether pretreatment with atorvastatin protects against atrial fibrillation following off-pump coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: the development of postoperative in-hospital atrial fibrillation confirmed by 12-lead ECG

secondary_outcome.measure: major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events rate, including cardiovascular death, postoperative stroke, myocardial infarction, or persistent atrial fibrillation,and identification of predictive markers for postoperative atrial fibrillation

intervention.description: atorvastatin 20 mg/d, started 3 days before surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- consecutive patients scheduled for the elective off-pump CABG surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- prior statin use
- previous episodes of atrial fibrillation
- impaired renal function with serum creatinine >2mg/dL
- serum aspartate aminotransferase or alanine aminotransferase concentrations more than 3 times the upper limit of normal
- a malignancy or inflammatory disease
